column1: 2018AGUFM.P13B..03N|2018|A New View of Apollo 17 Basaltic Samples|Neal
column2: C. R.|AGU Fall Meeting Abstracts|2018||P13B-03|The Apollo 17 high-Ti basalts were originally classified into types on the basis of whole rock data. Initial types were A
column5: and U. Type U represented unclassified basalts or those of uncertain affiliation. Four different types of volcanic glass have been described from the Apollo 17 sample collection based on color and composition: VLT
column8: and Orange. There are three subdivisions of the orange glasses
column9:
based upon major elements.

An elemental database of analyses from the Apollo 17 basaltic samples (i.e.
column10: both glasses and crystalline basalts) has been compiled in an attempt to re-examine the origins of the crystalline basalts and glasses. This study also highlights those samples where more data are required to properly classify them. The database was used to create results for elements that are common to both basalts and glasses. The "Unclassified" Type U samples were examined on several plots (e.g.
column12: Fig. 1) and assigned to Types A
column16: and D depending on their affinities. Where multiple analyses were reported for these samples
column17: averages were taken and data were only omitted if the analysis was clearly different from the others that have been reported. Remarkably
column21:
78579) did not plot consistently with the designated groups from Figure 1 and require more sophisticated analyses (larger sample mas needs to be homogenized).

The data show the following:

- Type B1 and B2 high-Ti basalts are distinct;

- Two new Type D basalts are defined (71597 and 78508 in addition to 79001);

- Type A
column22: B1 and C basalts fall on the same trends
column23:
as do Types B2 and D;

- Orange glass groups are distinct from high-Ti mare basalts;

- VLT glasses are similar in composition to the average VLT basalt compositions.

Ratios of REE and HFSE elements demonstrate that these basaltic materials are derived from distinct sources. This can also be extended to the transition elements
column24: but these can also be used to demonstrate that the crystalline basalt and glass groups are highly fractionated. The data from the Apollo 17 basaltic samples has allowed us to demonstrate mantle heterogeneity beneath Taurus Littrow. However
column25: the magmas produced from these sources underwent similar evolutionary pathways.|

column1: 1977LPSC....8.1429W|1977|Coarse-grained basalt 71597: a product of partial olivine accumulation.|Warner
column6: G. J.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|2||1429|Rock 71597
column7: a coarse-grained plagioclase-poikilitic basalt that contains 15.8% MgO and 19.3% modal olivine
column8: is described. Olivine and ilmenite crystals occur in two size generations
column11: and large ilmenite crystals are characterized. Since large olivine and ilmenite crystals with skeletal habits suggestive of crystallization under relatively rapid cooling are found in a rock whose texture is consonant with slower cooling
column12: it is suggested that the large skeletal crystals formed toward the more rapidly cooled margin of a flow and accumulated by gravitational crystal settling toward the flow's interior. In support of this hypothesis
column13: calculations indicate that the observed olivine compositions are approximately 10 mol% too Fe-rich to have crystallized from a melt of composition corresponding to that of 71597.|
